api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Articl.title: Enum ArticleStatus | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Articl.summary: Enum ArticleStatus Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Represents the user-facing status of an individual article within the RSS/Atom reader application. public enum ArticleStatus Fields Archived = 3 The user has intentionally removed the article from active/inbox views by archiving it. Behavior impact: Hidden from main timelines, unread views, and per-feed lists by default. Accessible only via "Archived" filter, search, or dedicated archive view. Eligible for eventual deletion after a configurable retention period (to save storage). Does not contribute to unread counters or clutter active feeds. When assigned: User clicks "Archive", "Done", or equivalent action. Bulk archive operations (e.g., archive all read in a feed). Typical transition: User can "unarchive"/"restore" back to Read or Unread. Recommendation: Treat Archived as a soft-delete â€” keep metadata and content for search/restore, but exclude from most queries by default for performance and UX. Read = 1 The user has opened, viewed, or explicitly marked the article as having been read. Behavior impact: Removed from default "unread" views and counters (unless user filters to show read items). Still visible in "all articles" or chronological views. No longer triggers new notifications. Often grayed out or styled differently in lists to indicate completion. When assigned: User opens the article in detail view. User uses bulk "mark as read" (up to current, all in feed, etc.). Some clients auto-mark as read when article is visible on screen for X seconds (configurable). Typical transitions: Back to Unread if user manually marks unread; to Starred or Archived. Starred = 2 The user has explicitly marked the article as important, favorite, or "starred" for later reference. Behavior impact: Appears in a dedicated "Starred"/"Favorites"/"Saved" section or filter. Often exempt from auto-archiving or cleanup policies. Highlighted visually (star icon, different background/color). May persist longer in local storage or sync even if original feed removes it. When assigned: User clicks star/favorite button on an article (from any prior status: Unread, Read, or even Archived in some flows). Business note: In this model, Starred replaces the previous status (e.g., a Read article becomes Starred, not Read+Starred). If compound states are needed (e.g., read AND starred), consider a separate flags table instead of a single enum. Unread = 0 The article is new and has not yet been opened or marked as read by the user. Behavior impact: Appears prominently in "unread" views, timelines, and feed lists. Contributes to unread counters/badges. May trigger notifications (push/email) depending on user settings. Default sorting often places Unread articles first (chronological descending within unread). When assigned: Immediately upon successful ingestion/sync of a new article from the feed. Never assigned automatically after initial creation. Typical transition: User opens/scrolls past the article â†’ changes to Read. Remarks This enumeration tracks the primary lifecycle and user interaction states for each article. It is used across the application to control visibility, filtering, sorting, notification behavior, and UI presentation of articles in lists, reading views, and dashboards. ArticleStatus directly influences: Which articles appear in the main "unread" or "all" feeds/timelines Badge counters (e.g., number of unread articles per feed or globally) Filtering options (e.g., "show only unread", "show starred", "show archived") Sync priorities and cleanup policies (e.g., archived articles may be eligible for deletion after a retention period) User actions like marking all as read, starring for later, or archiving to declutter Status changes are almost always triggered by explicit user actions (via UI or API) rather than automatically by the system, except in rare cases such as bulk "mark all as read" operations. The status is persisted per-user per-article (typically in a database table linking user ID, article GUID, and status value). Important business rules and design notes: Statuses are mutually exclusive â€” an article has exactly one status at any time. Starred is an orthogonal flag in many readers, but here it is modeled as a distinct primary status (meaning a starred article is no longer considered Unread/Read in the default view unless explicitly shown). Archiving is a user-initiated "cleanup" action; archived articles are hidden from main views by default but remain searchable and restorable. No automatic transitions occur (e.g., articles do not become Read just because time passed). When a new article is first ingested from a feed, it always starts as Unread.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.FeedHe.title: Enum FeedHealthStatus | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.FeedHe.summary: Enum FeedHealthStatus Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Represents the health and operational status of an RSS/Atom feed, determined by the outcome of recent update/fetch attempts and overall accessibility. public enum FeedHealthStatus Fields Error = 2 The feed has encountered multiple consecutive failures or exhibits a high error rate in recent attempts. Automatic updates are significantly restricted. Behavior: Polling interval is greatly increased or switched to manual-only (configurable). Prominent error indicators in UI (red icon, "Error" label). Exponential backoff or circuit-breaker logic is active. Notifications are usually suppressed until recovery is detected. When assigned: After 3â€“8 consecutive failures (exact threshold configurable). Persistent issues: 4xx/5xx errors, timeouts, SSL problems, malformed XML, etc. Healthy = 0 The feed is updating successfully with no significant issues detected in recent attempts. Behavior: Standard polling interval is used (default or user-defined). No warning indicators are displayed in the UI. Full eligibility for background refresh, article parsing, and notifications. When assigned: After multiple consecutive successful fetches. Error rate in the recent window is zero or negligible. Invalid = 4 The feed URL is invalid, permanently inaccessible, or points to content that cannot be processed as a valid syndication feed. Behavior: No further automatic refresh attempts are scheduled. Even manual refresh may be blocked or heavily warned against. Strong error UI state ("Invalid", "Gone", red indicators). Feed is typically hidden from active views by default (configurable). When assigned: Permanent HTTP errors (410 Gone, consistent 404). DNS failures, invalid SSL certificates, wrong content type (HTML instead of XML). Valid 200 response but content is not parseable as RSS/Atom/JSON Feed after retries. Business note: Invalid is generally a terminal state â€” recovery requires user correction or deletion. Paused = 3 The feed has been manually paused or disabled by the user. No automatic refresh activity occurs. Behavior: Completely excluded from all refresh queues and background tasks. No network requests are made until the user explicitly resumes the feed. UI displays paused state (grayed out, pause icon). Existing articles and metadata remain accessible in read-only mode. When assigned: User explicitly pauses the feed (e.g., too noisy, seasonal, temporary irrelevance). Some import flows (e.g. OPML) may initialize feeds as Paused. Important: System logic must never automatically resume a Paused feed. Warning = 1 The feed remains operational but exhibits intermittent problems (occasional failures, slow responses, partial content, rate limiting, transient HTTP errors, etc.). Behavior: Polling frequency may be moderately reduced (configurable). Subtle warning indicators appear in the UI (yellow/orange badge or icon). Mild retry backoff may begin on individual failures. Still fully eligible for notifications and content processing. When assigned: Recent error rate falls in the approximate 10â€“40% range (thresholds configurable). Temporary issues at the feed provider (rate limits, unstable hosting, etc.). Recommendation: Prolonged Warning states often precede degradation to Error. Remarks This enumeration drives multiple critical behaviors across the application: Whether the feed remains eligible for automatic background polling Visual indicators in the user interface (colors, icons, status badges) Retry frequency, exponential backoff, or circuit-breaker strategies during failures Generation (or suppression) of user notifications and alerts Filtering and sorting logic in feed lists, dashboards, and management views (e.g. "show only healthy feeds") The status is automatically evaluated and updated by the feed synchronization service after each refresh attempt. It is not based solely on the most recent fetch, but rather considers a sliding window of recent attempts â€” typically the last 3 to 10 fetches (the exact window size and weighting logic are configurable in the refresh policy settings). Key business rules and invariants: Only feeds in Healthy or Warning states are eligible for regular automatic polling under normal conditions. Feeds in Error or Invalid states trigger progressive restrictions: longer intervals, exponential backoff, or complete temporary exclusion from refresh queues. Paused is a user-controlled state that unconditionally blocks all automatic and background refresh activity â€” the system must never transition a Paused feed to another state without explicit user intervention via the UI. Most state transitions are driven by observed fetch results, except for Paused, which is exclusively set or cleared by direct user action. These rules help balance reliability, resource usage, and user experience while preventing unnecessary network requests to broken or intentionally disabled feeds.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.FeedUp.title: Enum FeedUpdateFrequency | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.FeedUp.summary: Enum FeedUpdateFrequency Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Defines the refresh interval options for automatic background polling of RSS/Atom feeds. public enum FeedUpdateFrequency Fields Daily = 1440 Attempt refresh approximately once per day (every 1440 minutes). Minimal polling frequency. Best for archival feeds, podcasts, or extremely low-activity sources. Every12Hours = 720 Attempt refresh approximately every 12 hours. Very conservative polling. Ideal for low-update-frequency sources or strict power-saving scenarios. Every15Minutes = 15 Attempt refresh approximately every 15 minutes. High-frequency option. Suitable only for critical real-time feeds. May trigger rate limits or increased battery/data usage. Every30Minutes = 30 Attempt refresh approximately every 30 minutes. Balanced option for feeds that update several times per day (news, blogs with frequent posts). Every3Hours = 180 Attempt refresh approximately every 3 hours. Recommended for most users and moderately active feeds. Significantly reduces background activity. Every6Hours = 360 Attempt refresh approximately every 6 hours. Suitable for feeds that update infrequently (daily digests, weekly publications). EveryHour = 60 Attempt refresh approximately every 60 minutes (hourly). Common default for general news and blog feeds. Good balance between freshness and resource consumption. Manual = 0 No automatic polling is performed. Updates occur only when manually triggered by the user. Behavior: Feed is excluded from all background refresh schedules. Conserves maximum resources (battery, data, network). Useful for rarely updated feeds, metered connections, or power-saving mode. Remarks This enumeration controls how frequently the system attempts to fetch new content from each subscribed feed when automatic updates are enabled (i.e., the feed is not in Paused, Error, or Invalid state). Key behaviors and system impacts: Determines the minimum time (in minutes) between two consecutive refresh attempts for a feed. Directly affects battery usage, data consumption, server load, and perceived freshness of content. Used by the background scheduler/refresh queue to calculate next poll time. Can be overridden per-feed or globally via user settings. More frequent intervals (15â€“60 min) are suitable for news-heavy or real-time feeds; longer intervals reduce resource usage. Business rules and recommendations: Manual disables all automatic polling â€” refreshes occur only when the user explicitly triggers them. Values represent minutes between refreshes (except Manual which is a special case). The actual polling time may be slightly delayed due to device sleep, network conditions, or queue prioritization. Very frequent polling (Every15Minutes) should be discouraged or limited to a small number of feeds to avoid rate-limiting by feed hosts and excessive battery drain. Default recommendation for most users: EveryHour or Every3Hours balances freshness and efficiency. Feeds in Warning or Error states may have their effective frequency temporarily reduced regardless of this setting.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Logica.title: Enum LogicalOperator | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Logica.summary: Enum LogicalOperator Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Specifies the logical operator used to combine multiple conditions or filters in queries, rules, or search expressions within the RSS reader application. public enum LogicalOperator Fields AND = 0 All conditions must be satisfied (conjunction). Effect: Narrows down results significantly. Common in precise filtering: "has tag X AND published after date Y AND contains keyword Z". Higher performance cost in large datasets due to fewer early exits in evaluation. OR = 1 At least one condition must be satisfied (disjunction). Effect: Expands result sets (union of matches). Common in discovery/search: "contains keyword A OR keyword B OR keyword C". Usually faster evaluation as any true condition short-circuits the check. Remarks This enumeration defines how multiple criteria are evaluated when building complex filters for articles, feeds, or search operations. Typical usage scenarios include: Combining keyword/tag/category filters in article search or smart feeds Defining inclusion/exclusion rules in custom feed views or notification rules Building advanced filtering logic for dashboards, saved searches, or automation Combining conditions in user-defined rules (e.g., "star articles that match ALL of these tags" vs "ANY") Business rules and behavioral impact: AND requires **all** specified conditions to be true for the item to match (restrictive/narrowing). OR requires **at least one** condition to be true for the item to match (inclusive/broadening). The operator is usually applied between conditions of the same group/level; nested groups may use different operators. Default behavior in UI (when not explicitly chosen) is typically OR for keyword/tag searches (broader discovery) and AND for strict filtering rules. Changing the operator can dramatically alter result sets â€” users should be warned when switching between AND/OR in rule editors. In most implementations, this value is stored per-filter-group or per-rule to allow mixed logic (e.g., (A AND B) OR C). Recommendation: When exposing this in UI, label clearly as "All of these" (AND) vs "Any of these" (OR) to improve user understanding and reduce configuration errors.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Module.title: Enum ModuleStatus | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Module.summary: Enum ModuleStatus Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Module status enumeration. public enum ModuleStatus Fields Error = 7 Module is in error state. Initialized = 2 Module is initialized but not started. Initializing = 1 Module is initializing. NotInitialized = 0 Module is not initialized. Running = 4 Module is running. Starting = 3 Module is starting. Stopped = 6 Module is stopped. Stopping = 5 Module is stopping.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Notifi.title: Enum NotificationAction | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Notifi.summary: Enum NotificationAction Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Represents the different types of user interactions or resolutions applied to a notification generated by the RSS reader application (new articles, feed errors, sync events, etc.). public enum NotificationAction Fields Archive = 4 User clicked a custom action button to archive the related article/feed item. Behavior: Applies archive status to the associated article. Marks notification as handled. Clicked = 1 The user clicked/tapped the main body of the notification. Behavior: Typically navigates to the related content (article, feed, settings page). Often triggers secondary actions (e.g., mark article as read). Marks notification as resolved. Custom1 = 8 First reserved slot for a context-specific custom action button. Meaning depends on notification type (e.g., "Mute this feed", "Unsubscribe", "Share", etc.). Should be documented per notification category when used. Custom2 = 9 Second reserved slot for a context-specific custom action button. Meaning depends on notification type (e.g., "View all in feed", "Report issue", etc.). Should be documented per notification category when used. Dismissed = 2 The user explicitly dismissed or closed the notification (swipe away, close button, etc.). Behavior: Removes the notification from view and prevents automatic re-showing for this event. No secondary actions are triggered. MarkAsRead = 5 User clicked a custom action button to mark the related article as read. Behavior: Sets article status to Read (if applicable). Resolves the notification. None = 0 The notification has not been interacted with yet (still visible or pending in notification center). Behavior: Notification remains eligible for display/re-display. Default initial state when a notification is first created. OpenInBrowser = 7 User clicked a custom action button to open the article/feed in the system web browser. Behavior: Launches external browser with the content URL. May or may not mark content as read (configurable). Resolves the notification. Snoozed = 3 The user chose to snooze/postpone the notification. Behavior: Hides the notification temporarily (duration configured by user or default). Notification may reappear after snooze period expires. Does not resolve the underlying event permanently. Star = 6 User clicked a custom action button to star/favorite the related article. Behavior: Sets article status to Starred (or adds star flag). Resolves the notification. Remarks This enumeration tracks how (or if) the user responded to a displayed notification. It is used to: Update notification state in the UI and persistence layer Collect analytics on user behavior with notifications Prevent duplicate notifications for the same event Trigger secondary actions (e.g., mark article as read when notification is clicked) Support snooze/dismiss/archive workflows Notification actions are typically recorded when the user interacts with a system notification (toast, banner, tray icon popup) or with in-app notification elements. Business rules and behavioral implications: None indicates the notification is still visible/unresolved â€” it may continue to appear in notification center or re-surface on app open. Most actions (Clicked, Dismissed, etc.) are terminal: they mark the notification as handled and prevent further automatic re-display for the same underlying event. Snoozed is temporary â€” the notification is hidden for a user-configured period (e.g., 1 hour, until tomorrow) and may reappear afterward. Actions like MarkAsRead, Star, Archive often cascade to the related article/feed (e.g., clicking a "new article" notification may set Clicked and simultaneously mark the article as Read). Custom1 and Custom2 are reserved for future or context-specific buttons defined per notification type (e.g., "Unsubscribe", "Mute feed", "Share", etc.). Their exact meaning depends on the notification payload. Once an action other than None or Snoozed is recorded, the notification should no longer be re-presented automatically for the same trigger.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Notifi.title: Enum NotificationPriority | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Notifi.summary: Enum NotificationPriority Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Defines the urgency level and presentation behavior of notifications in the RSS reader application. public enum NotificationPriority Fields Critical = 3 Highest urgency: demands immediate user attention and action. Typical scenarios: Authentication expired â€” login required to continue syncing Critical storage or database capacity warning (risk of data loss) Security/privacy alert (e.g., potential malicious feed content detected) Complete sync failure preventing any updates for extended period Behavior: Strong, repeating alert sound/vibration Persistent full-screen or heads-up display requiring interaction Usually bypasses Do Not Disturb / Focus modes (subject to OS rules) Often includes mandatory action buttons (e.g., "Fix Now", "Retry", "Login") Use extremely sparingly to preserve user trust in notifications High = 2 Elevated urgency: uses persistent or repeating alerts to gain attention. Typical scenarios: New articles from high-priority/starred feeds or matching critical filters Prolonged feed outage on important sources Significant application events (e.g., major update available) Behavior: Plays persistent/repeating sound or vibration pattern Shows as a prominent, longer-lasting banner or heads-up notification Higher likelihood of bypassing quiet hours (with user permission) Appears near the top of notification lists Low = 0 Lowest urgency: completely silent and non-intrusive. Typical scenarios: Background sync completed without issues Minor status updates or batch summaries Low-priority informational messages Behavior: No sound, no vibration, no screen wake Appears as a short-lived toast or collapsed notification Stays in notification history but does not demand attention Fully respects quiet hours and focus modes Normal = 1 Standard urgency: uses a single, non-disruptive alert. Typical scenarios: New articles from regular feeds (when notifications enabled) Feed successfully recovered from warning/error state Daily/weekly unread digest summaries Behavior: Plays default notification sound once Shows as a standard toast/banner; persists in notification center May briefly wake the screen (platform-dependent) Most common priority for routine application events Remarks This enumeration determines how a notification is delivered to the user, including sound, vibration, persistence, screen wake behavior, and whether user interaction is mandatory. The priority level is assigned when the notification is created, based on the nature and importance of the triggering event. Priority influences the following aspects: Sound and vibration patterns (silent, single alert, repeating, or escalating) Notification display style (transient toast vs persistent banner/heads-up) Ability to bypass Do Not Disturb / Focus modes (platform-dependent) Positioning in the notification shade/center (higher priorities appear first) Requirement for explicit user acknowledgment or action Important business rules and guidelines: Use Low and Normal for the vast majority of events to prevent notification fatigue. High and especially Critical should be reserved for genuinely urgent situations that demand immediate user attention. User preferences may override or cap notification priority per category or globally. On Android, each priority typically maps to a distinct notification channel with its own sound/vibration settings. On iOS/macOS, priority affects interruption level and banner style (temporary vs persistent). Default priority for new article notifications: Normal

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Notifi.title: Enum NotificationType | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.Notifi.summary: Enum NotificationType Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Specifies the delivery/presentation method for notifications in the RSS reader application. public enum NotificationType Fields Banner = 4 Prominent visual banner (heads-up, persistent, or expanded style), typically without sound unless combined with priority. Typical use cases: High-priority events requiring stronger visual emphasis Notifications that should remain visible longer than a standard toast Critical alerts on platforms that distinguish banner styles Behavior: Displays as a larger, more noticeable banner/pop-up (may cover more screen area or persist longer) No automatic sound (sound controlled separately via NotificationPriority) Often used for elevated-attention but non-audible alerts Both = 2 Both visual notification (toast/banner) and audible alert (sound/vibration). Typical use cases: Standard new article notifications when sound is enabled Medium-to-high importance events that should catch attention User's default preference for important feeds Behavior: Shows visual element + plays notification sound once Most common and expected delivery method for alerting notifications Combines visibility with immediate awareness Silent = 3 No visual or audible interruption â€” notification is logged internally only. Typical use cases: Successful background operations (sync completed, feed refreshed silently) Debug/telemetry events visible only in logs or app diagnostics Events explicitly muted by user per category Behavior: No user-visible popup, banner, sound, or vibration May still be recorded in an in-app notification history or activity log Zero interruption to user experience Sound = 1 Audible alert only (sound/vibration), without any visual element on screen. Typical use cases: Rare â€” mostly for very specific accessibility scenarios or legacy behaviors Subtle reminders when user is already looking at the app Behavior: Plays sound (and possibly vibration) but shows nothing on screen May not be supported or visible on all platforms (many require visual pairing with sound) Use cautiously to avoid confusing or annoying users Recommendation: Prefer Both or Toast in most cases. Toast = 0 Visual notification only (toast-style popup or entry in notification center). No sound is played. Typical use cases: Low-to-normal priority new article notifications when user has disabled sounds Informational messages that do not require immediate attention Behavior: Shows a brief toast or persistent notification entry No audible alert Respects mute/quiet modes fully Remarks This enumeration defines how a notification is delivered to the user â€” whether visually, audibly, both, or silently in the background â€” independent of its priority or content. It controls the immediate user experience at the moment of delivery. NotificationType affects: Whether a visual element (toast, banner, popup) is shown on screen Whether a sound alert is played (regardless of device volume/mute state) Whether the notification is completely silent and only logged internally How intrusive the notification feels to the user at the time it is triggered Important business rules and usage guidelines: The type is typically chosen based on the event's nature and user-configured preferences for specific notification categories (new articles, feed errors, sync status, etc.). Silent should be used for background/logging-only events that the user should never be interrupted for (e.g., successful background sync, minor housekeeping). Sound alone (without visual) is rare and usually discouraged â€” most platforms require a visual component when playing sound for accessibility and UX reasons. Banner is intended for more attention-grabbing visual presentation (larger, persistent, or heads-up style) compared to a standard Toast. Final delivery may still be modulated by device settings (Do Not Disturb, notification channels, app-level mute, screen state), but NotificationType defines the application's intended delivery intent. Default for most article-related notifications: Both or Toast (depending on user preference for sound).

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleAc.title: Enum RuleActionType | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleAc.summary: Enum RuleActionType Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Defines the possible automated actions that can be executed when an article matches the conditions of a user-defined rule or filter in the RSS reader application. public enum RuleActionType Fields ApplyTags = 4 Applies one or more user-defined tags/labels to the article. Behavior: Adds specified tags to the article's tag collection. Enables filtering, searching, and organization by tag. Requires associated tag IDs/names as rule parameters. ArchiveArticle = 9 Archives the matching article (moves to archive, hides from main views). Behavior: Sets article status to Archived. Hides from active lists but keeps for search/restore. Common for "processed" or low-value articles. DeleteArticle = 8 Permanently deletes the matching article from the user's library. Behavior: Removes article completely (usually irreversible without backup). Should include user confirmation on rule creation. Useful for spam, duplicates, or outdated content filters. HighlightArticle = 10 Applies a visual highlight (e.g., background color) to the article in lists/views. Behavior: Associates a specific color/style with the article. Requires color parameter (e.g., hex code or predefined theme color ID). Helps visually prioritize important matches (e.g., red for urgent, green for approved). MarkAsFavorite = 3 Marks the article as a favorite (alternative naming for starred). Behavior: Functionally identical to MarkAsStarred in most implementations. Retained for compatibility or user preference in naming. Avoid using both in the same rule to prevent confusion. MarkAsRead = 0 Automatically marks the matching article as read. Behavior: Sets article status to Read. Removes from unread counters and default "unread" views. Common for low-priority or already-seen content (e.g., newsletters user skims). MarkAsStarred = 2 Marks the article as starred/favorited for later reference. Behavior: Sets article status to Starred (or adds starred flag if compound states are supported). Makes article appear in "Starred" / "Favorites" views. Often exempt from auto-archive/cleanup policies. MarkAsUnread = 1 Forces the article to remain (or become) unread, even if previously viewed. Behavior: Sets or resets article status to Unread. Useful for high-priority matches that should always demand attention. MoveToCategory = 5 Moves the article (or assigns it) to a specific user-defined category/folder. Behavior: Changes the article's category assignment. Feeds may support per-article categories independent of feed-level folders. Requires category ID as parameter. PlaySound = 7 Plays a custom or predefined sound alert when the article matches. Behavior: Plays an audible alert (device-dependent). Should respect mute/vibration settings. Use sparingly to avoid annoyance. SendNotification = 6 Triggers a user notification for the matching article. Behavior: Generates a notification (toast, banner, push) even if global article notifications are off. Priority and type configurable per rule or globally. Common for keyword alerts (e.g., "job opening", "breaking news"). Remarks This enumeration represents the actions available in the rule engine / smart filter system. Rules allow users to automate article processing based on criteria such as keywords, authors, publication date, feed source, content patterns, or other metadata. Each rule can trigger zero or more actions when an article matches. Actions are applied immediately after ingestion/sync (or on first evaluation for existing articles). Key behavioral impacts and system considerations: Actions modify article state (status, tags, category) or trigger side effects (notifications, sounds, deletion). Multiple actions can be combined in one rule (e.g., MarkAsStarred + ApplyTags + SendNotification). Order of execution is typically the order defined in the rule configuration. Some actions are mutually exclusive or have precedence (e.g., DeleteArticle usually overrides others). Actions are executed server-side (if cloud sync) or client-side, depending on architecture. User rules should be evaluated efficiently to avoid performance impact during bulk syncs. Business rules and recommendations: Irreversible actions (DeleteArticle, ArchiveArticle) should require explicit user confirmation when creating/editing rules. MarkAsFavorite is included for backward compatibility or alternative naming; prefer MarkAsStarred in new implementations if they represent the same concept. HighlightArticle requires an associated color or style parameter (not stored in the enum value itself). Actions like PlaySound and SendNotification should respect global notification settings and device state. Default behavior: new articles start as Unread unless a rule changes their status.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleFi.title: Enum RuleFieldTarget | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleFi.summary: Enum RuleFieldTarget Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Specifies the target field(s) of an article where a rule condition (e.g., keyword match, pattern search, or value comparison) is evaluated in the RSS reader's rule/filter engine. public enum RuleFieldTarget Fields AllFields = 4 The condition must be true in all searched fields (usually title AND content). Behavior: Restrictive: term must appear in both title and content (or all targeted fields). Reduces false positives significantly. Internally applies logical AND across fields. Higher performance cost than single-field targets. AnyField = 5 The condition is satisfied if true in any of the searched fields (usually title OR content). Behavior: Inclusive: term found in title, content, or both. Broadens matches â€” useful for general keyword discovery. Internally applies logical OR across fields. May increase false positives compared to narrower targets. Author = 2 The condition is evaluated against the article's author name(s) or byline. Behavior: Matches single or multiple authors (comma-separated or array). Common for author-specific rules (e.g., "from trusted journalist X"). Usually case-insensitive exact or partial match. Categories = 3 The condition is evaluated against the article's assigned categories, tags, or labels. Behavior: Checks per-article tags or inherited feed categories. Typically supports "contains tag X" or "has any of [X, Y]". Fast if tags are stored/indexed as arrays or sets. Content = 1 The condition is evaluated only against the article's main content/body text. Behavior: Checks full article text (or summary/excerpt if full content not available). Slower than title-only but catches deeper context. Useful for rules like "contains technical term" or "mentions specific company". Title = 0 The condition is evaluated only against the article's title/headline. Behavior: Fastest evaluation â€” title is usually a short indexed field. Most relevant for catching important topics from headlines. Recommended default for keyword-based rules. Remarks This enumeration determines which part(s) of an article are inspected when applying a rule condition. It is used in combination with operators (contains, equals, starts with, regex match, etc.) and values to define precise matching criteria. Typical usage in rule definitions: RuleCondition { Field = RuleFieldTarget.Title, Operator = Contains, Value = "urgent" } RuleCondition { Field = RuleFieldTarget.AllFields, Operator = MatchesRegex, Value = @"\bimportant\b" } Behavioral impact and system considerations: Choosing a narrow target (Title, Author) improves performance and reduces false positives compared to broader targets (AllFields). Categories typically refers to the article's tags/labels or feed categories (exact semantics depend on whether tags are per-article or inherited from feed). AllFields and AnyField perform searches across multiple parts of the article, usually title + content (and sometimes author/description if indexed). Full-text search targets may be case-insensitive and support stemming/tokenization depending on the underlying search implementation. When using AllFields or AnyField, the rule engine may apply different logical operators internally (AND for AllFields, OR for AnyField). Business rules and recommendations: Default recommended target for keyword rules: Title (fastest, most relevant for headlines). Use Content for deeper semantic matches (e.g., body text contains specific phrases). AllFields is convenient for broad keyword alerts but may increase false positives and slightly slow evaluation during bulk syncs. AnyField is useful when users want to catch a term anywhere prominent without requiring it in every field. For performance-critical environments, discourage widespread use of AllFields and AnyField on very large article sets unless indexed properly. When exposing in UI, label clearly: "Title only", "Article body", "Author", "Tags/Categories", "Title and content (all must match)", "Title or content (any match)".

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleOp.title: Enum RuleOperator | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleOp.summary: Enum RuleOperator Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Defines the comparison operators available for evaluating conditions in the RSS reader's rule/filter engine. public enum RuleOperator Fields Between = 11 The target field value falls within the specified inclusive range (minimum to maximum). Behavior: Requires two values: minimum and maximum (inclusive). Works with numeric values (article length, word count, etc.). Works with date/time values (publication date, last updated, etc.). For strings, uses lexical/alphabetical comparison (rarely used). Example: WordCount Between 500 and 1000 matches articles with 500-1000 words. Example: Published Between "2025-01-01" and "2025-01-31" matches January 2025 articles. Implementation notes: Both values are required; UI should enforce min â‰¤ max. Parsing failures should fail the condition gracefully (returns false). For dates, consider timezone handling (typically UTC). Inclusive boundaries: value â‰¥ min AND value â‰¤ max. Contains = 0 The target field contains the specified substring (case-insensitive by default). Behavior: Partial text match anywhere in the field. Most frequently used operator for keyword-based rules. Example: Title Contains "breaking" matches "Breaking News Today". EndsWith = 3 The target field ends with the specified suffix. Behavior: Checks only the end of the string. Common for file extensions, URL patterns, or title endings. Equals = 1 The target field exactly matches the specified value (case-insensitive by default). Behavior: Full exact match required (no wildcards). Ideal for precise filters (author name, exact tag, specific title). GreaterThan = 7 The target field (parsed as date or number) is greater than the specified value. Behavior: Used primarily for publication dates (e.g., newer than X days ago). Requires field to be convertible to DateTime or numeric type. Example: Published > "2025-01-01" IsEmpty = 9 The target field is empty, null, or contains only whitespace. Behavior: Does not use comparison value. Useful for detecting missing metadata (e.g., no author, empty content). IsNotEmpty = 10 The target field is NOT empty (has content beyond whitespace). Behavior: Negation of IsEmpty. Common for ensuring field presence before other conditions. LessThan = 8 The target field (parsed as date or number) is less than the specified value. Behavior: Used for older content (e.g., older than 7 days). Same parsing requirements as GreaterThan. NotBetween = 12 The target field value falls outside the specified inclusive range (less than minimum OR greater than maximum). Behavior: Negation of Between. Requires two values: minimum and maximum (inclusive). Matches if value is less than minimum OR greater than maximum. Useful for outliers, old articles, or extremely long content. Example: WordCount NotBetween 100 and 1000 matches very short or very long articles. Implementation notes: Both values are required; UI should enforce min â‰¤ max. Same parsing requirements as Between. Edge case: If min == max, this matches everything except that exact value. NotContains = 4 The target field does NOT contain the specified substring. Behavior: Negation of Contains. Useful for exclusion rules (e.g., ignore promotional content). NotEquals = 5 The target field is NOT exactly equal to the specified value. Behavior: Negation of Equals. Helps exclude specific known values. Regex = 6 The target field matches the provided regular expression pattern. Behavior: Full regex matching (case sensitivity depends on implementation/flags). Most powerful but slowest and most error-prone operator. Requires validation of regex syntax in UI. Example: \b[A-Z]{3}-\d{4}\b for codes like ABC-1234. StartsWith = 2 The target field begins with the specified prefix. Behavior: Checks only the start of the string. Useful for patterns like titles starting with "[Update]", "[Video]", etc. Remarks This enumeration specifies how a rule condition compares the value of a target field (title, content, author, etc.) against the user-provided value or pattern. The operator determines the matching logic applied during article evaluation. Key considerations for operator selection and behavior: String-based operators (Contains, Equals, etc.) are typically case-insensitive by default (configurable per rule or globally). Numeric/date operators (GreaterThan, LessThan) are only valid when the target field is a date, numeric value, or can be parsed as such (e.g., publication date). Regex supports full regular expression patterns (PCRE or .NET flavor, depending on implementation). IsEmpty and IsNotEmpty ignore the comparison value and check field presence/content length. Operators are evaluated per condition; multiple conditions in a rule use logical AND/OR grouping. Business rules and usage recommendations: Most common operators for keyword rules: Contains (broad) and Regex (precise). Use Equals for exact matches (e.g., author name, specific category/tag). StartsWith and EndsWith are useful for domain-specific patterns (e.g., titles starting with "[Sponsored]", URLs ending in ".pdf"). Date-based operators (GreaterThan, LessThan) require the field to be parsed as DateTimeOffset or similar; invalid parsing should fail the condition gracefully. NotContains and NotEquals are useful for exclusion rules (e.g., "do not star articles containing 'ad' or 'promo'"). Between and NotBetween are ideal for range-based filtering (e.g., word count ranges, date ranges). UI validation: Disable invalid operators for certain field types (e.g., hide date operators when target is Title/Content). Performance note: Regex and full-text searches can be expensive on large datasets; use judiciously and prefer simpler operators when possible.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleSc.title: Enum RuleScope | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.RuleSc.summary: Enum RuleScope Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Defines the scope of application for a user-defined rule or filter in the RSS reader. The scope determines which feeds or articles the rule conditions and actions are evaluated against. public enum RuleScope Fields AllFeeds = 0 The rule applies to articles from all subscribed feeds in the user's account. Behavior: Evaluated against every incoming or existing article, regardless of feed or category. Most common scope for global behaviors (e.g., "star anything mentioning 'AI'"). Highest potential performance impact during large syncs. CurrentView = 3 The rule applies only to articles that are currently visible in the user's active view (based on current filters, search, selected feed/category, unread status, etc.). Behavior: Evaluated against the current filtered/selected set of articles at the moment of rule execution. Not applied automatically during background sync â€” typically triggered by explicit user action (e.g., "Apply rules to this view", bulk operations). Fastest scope â€” only a small subset of articles is considered. Common for temporary/ad-hoc actions (bulk tagging visible results, mark-as-read current page). May behave inconsistently if view changes rapidly; UI should warn or lock scope during application. SpecificCategories = 2 The rule applies only to articles belonging to one or more selected categories/folders. Behavior: Requires associated category IDs in the rule definition. Useful when feeds are grouped logically (e.g., "Work", "Hobbies", "News") and rules should respect that grouping. Allows inheritance: articles inherit category from their parent feed if per-article categories are not used. SpecificFeeds = 1 The rule applies only to articles from a specific list of selected feeds. Behavior: Requires associated feed IDs in the rule definition. Ideal for feed-specific automation (e.g., auto-archive newsletters, notify on job board updates). More efficient than AllFeeds when targeting few feeds. Remarks This enumeration controls the breadth of a rule's influence â€” from applying globally to all subscribed feeds down to only the currently visible articles in the user's active view. It helps users organize rules efficiently and prevent unintended side effects on unrelated content. Behavioral impact and system usage: The scope is evaluated at rule execution time (usually during article ingestion or on-demand re-evaluation). Rules with narrower scopes (CurrentView) are typically faster and more targeted. Broader scopes (AllFeeds) affect more articles but may increase processing time during bulk syncs. Scope is independent of conditions â€” even if conditions match, the article must fall within the scope to apply actions. UI should clearly indicate scope when creating/editing rules (e.g., dropdown: "Apply to all feeds", "Selected feeds only", etc.). Business rules and recommendations: Default scope for new rules: AllFeeds (broadest, most common for global behaviors like "star articles with keyword X"). Use SpecificFeeds or SpecificCategories for feed-specific automation (e.g., archive everything from "Promotions" feed, highlight posts from "Tech News" category). CurrentView is intended for temporary, context-aware rules (e.g., bulk mark-as-read in the current search/filter view, or apply tags to visible selection). When scope is SpecificFeeds or SpecificCategories, the rule configuration must include a list of feed IDs or category IDs; otherwise, the rule is inactive. Rules scoped to CurrentView should only be triggered via explicit user actions (e.g., "Apply rules to current view" button), not automatically on sync. Performance note: Avoid combining very broad scopes with expensive conditions (e.g., regex on AllFields) unless the user base and dataset size justify it.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncPr.title: Enum SyncPriority | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncPr.summary: Enum SyncPriority Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Priority levels for task scheduling. public enum SyncPriority Fields Critical = 3 Critical priority - must run immediately. High = 2 High priority - user-triggered or critical tasks. Low = 0 Low priority - runs when system is idle. Medium = 1 Medium priority - normal background tasks.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncSt.title: Enum SyncStatus | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncSt.summary: Enum SyncStatus Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Represents the overall synchronization status. public enum SyncStatus Fields Error = 5 Service is in error state. Paused = 3 Service is paused (no new tasks start). Running = 2 Service is running normally. Starting = 1 Service is starting up. Stopped = 0 Service is stopped. Stopping = 4 Service is shutting down.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncTa.title: Enum SyncTaskStatus | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncTa.summary: Enum SyncTaskStatus Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Status of an individual synchronization task. public enum SyncTaskStatus Fields Cancelled = 5 Task was cancelled. Completed = 3 Task completed successfully. Disabled = 6 Task is disabled in configuration. Failed = 4 Task failed with error. Idle = 0 Task is idle, waiting for schedule. Running = 2 Task is currently running. Scheduled = 1 Task is scheduled to run soon.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncTa.title: Enum SyncTaskType | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.SyncTa.summary: Enum SyncTaskType Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Types of synchronization tasks managed by the coordinator. public enum SyncTaskType Fields ArticleCleanup = 2 Article retention cleanup. BackupCreation = 3 Database and settings backup creation. CacheMaintenance = 6 Cache maintenance (image cache, etc.). FeedUpdate = 0 Feed content updates and article fetching. FullSync = 7 Full synchronization cycle. RuleProcessing = 5 Rule engine processing. StatisticsUpdate = 4 Statistics recalculation. TagProcessing = 1 Auto-tagging rule processing.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums.html.title: Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums | NeonSuit RSS Reader API

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Extensions.S.title: Class StringExtensions | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Extensions.S.summary: Class StringExtensions Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Extensions Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Provides extension methods for string manipulation, particularly useful for cleaning and processing RSS/Atom feed content. public static class StringExtensions Inheritance object StringExtensions Inherited Members object.Equals(object) object.Equals(object, object) object.GetHashCode() object.GetType() object.MemberwiseClone() object.ReferenceEquals(object, object) object.ToString() Remarks This static class contains utility extensions for common string operations in the RSS reader domain, such as HTML tag removal for safe summary generation and content preview. All methods are designed to be null-safe, performant, and suitable for processing potentially malformed feed data from external sources. Performance note: Methods use compiled regular expressions where applicable to minimize overhead on repeated calls (e.g., during feed parsing). Methods StripHtml(string?) Removes all HTML tags from the input string and trims whitespace, producing a plain-text version. public static string StripHtml(this string? input) Parameters input string The input string potentially containing HTML markup (e.g., from RSS description or content). Returns string A clean plain-text string with all HTML tags removed and normalized whitespace; never null. Examples string dirty = "Hello   world! <script>alert(1)</script>"; string clean = dirty.StripHtml(); // Returns: "Hello world! alert(1)" Remarks This method is optimized for RSS/Atom feed summaries and descriptions: - Strips all HTML tags using a compiled regex - Replaces common non-breaking spaces ( ) with regular spaces - Normalizes line breaks to single spaces - Trims leading/trailing whitespace Safe for large inputs: does not load full DOM or use heavy HTML parsers. Sufficient for most feed use cases; does not attempt to preserve formatting or handle malformed HTML perfectly. Performance: Regex is compiled once at startup for fast repeated execution during feed sync.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Extensions.h.title: Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Extensions | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Extensions.h.summary: Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Extensions Classes StringExtensions Provides extension methods for string manipulation, particularly useful for cleaning and processing RSS/Atom feed content.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Helpers.Json.title: Class JsonValidationHelper | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Helpers.Json.summary: Class JsonValidationHelper Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Helpers Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Provides helper methods for validating JSON strings during rule processing, configuration loading, and data deserialization in the RSS reader application. public static class JsonValidationHelper Inheritance object JsonValidationHelper Inherited Members object.Equals(object) object.Equals(object, object) object.GetHashCode() object.GetType() object.MemberwiseClone() object.ReferenceEquals(object, object) object.ToString() Remarks These validation helpers are used primarily when: Storing or loading complex rule parameters (e.g., list of feed IDs, tag arrays) Validating user-provided JSON in custom filter conditions or action payloads Ensuring configuration fields that store serialized data remain parseable Key behavioral notes: Null or whitespace-only input is treated as valid (represents "no value" or empty collection). Validation is strict: even valid JSON that deserializes to null is rejected when expecting a value. Exceptions thrown are ArgumentException with clear field context for easier debugging and user feedback. Inner JsonException is preserved as inner exception for detailed diagnostics. No logging is performed inside these methods â€” logging should be handled by the calling layer if needed. Usage recommendations: Call these methods early in rule/command validation pipelines to fail fast on malformed data. When validating arrays/lists, prefer the expectIntArray overload for common cases (feed IDs, tag IDs). For complex types, use the generic EnsureValidJson<T>(string?, string) overload. Avoid using these helpers for very large JSON payloads â€” consider streaming validation instead. Methods EnsureValidJson(string?, string, bool) Validates that the provided string is either null/empty/whitespace or contains valid JSON. When expectIntArray is true, also ensures it deserializes to a non-null integer array. public static void EnsureValidJson(string? json, string fieldName, bool expectIntArray = false) Parameters json string The JSON string to validate (can be null or empty). fieldName string The name of the field or property being validated â€” used in exception messages for traceability. expectIntArray bool If true, validates that the JSON is a non-null array of integers (common for ID lists). If false, only checks for syntactically valid JSON. Exceptions ArgumentException Thrown when the JSON is invalid, or when expecting an int array but the result is null or not an array. EnsureValidJson<T>(string?, string) Validates that the provided string is either null/empty/whitespace or contains valid JSON that successfully deserializes to the expected type T. public static void EnsureValidJson<T>(string? json, string fieldName) Parameters json string The JSON string to validate (can be null or empty). fieldName string The name of the field or property being validated â€” used in exception messages. Type Parameters T The expected target type after deserialization (e.g., List<string>, CustomRulePayload). Exceptions ArgumentException Thrown when the JSON is invalid or deserializes to null when a value is expected.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Helpers.html.title: Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Helpers | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Helpers.html.summary: Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Helpers Classes JsonValidationHelper Provides helper methods for validating JSON strings during rule processing, configuration loading, and data deserialization in the RSS reader application.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.D.title: Interface IRSSReaderDbContext | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.D.summary: Interface IRSSReaderDbContext Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.Database Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Core interface for the RSS Reader's Entity Framework Core database context. Defines standardized access to database operations, transaction management, raw SQL execution, maintenance tasks, and basic statistics â€” with full async support. public interface IRSSReaderDbContext : IAsyncDisposable Inherited Members IAsyncDisposable.DisposeAsync() Remarks This interface abstracts the underlying DbContext implementation and is intended to be: Implemented by the actual DbContext class (e.g., RssReaderDbContext : DbContext, IRssReaderDbContext) Injected via dependency injection into services, repositories, and background workers Used consistently across the application to ensure proper async/await usage and transaction safety Key design principles: All mutating operations should prefer transactional execution (via ExecuteInTransactionAsync) Raw SQL methods are provided for performance-critical or SQLite-specific operations (VACUUM, PRAGMA, etc.) Maintenance methods (Backup, Vacuum, Reset) are exposed for admin/debug flows and automated cleanup Statistics are lightweight and suitable for periodic health checks or UI dashboard display Important notes for implementers and consumers: The context is expected to use SQLite (based on DatabasePath and Vacuum/Backup methods) Implementations should handle connection pooling, retry logic, and concurrency appropriately Do not call SaveChanges/SaveChangesAsync directly on the underlying DbContext from consumers â€” use transactional wrappers Cancellation support is mandatory on all async methods Properties DatabasePath Gets the full file-system path to the SQLite database file. string? DatabasePath { get; } Property Value string Remarks Used for backup operations, file existence checks, and diagnostics. Returns null if using in-memory database (testing scenarios). Methods ApplyMigrationsAsync(CancellationToken) Explicitly applies any pending EF Core migrations to the database. Task ApplyMigrationsAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cancellationToken CancellationToken Returns Task Remarks Usually called internally by EnsureDatabaseCreatedAsync, but exposed for manual migration scenarios. BackupAsync(string, CancellationToken) Creates a full backup copy of the SQLite database file. Task BackupAsync(string backupPath, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters backupPath string Target path where the backup file will be saved (must include .db extension). cancellationToken CancellationToken Returns Task Remarks Uses SQLite backup API for consistency and minimal locking. Throws if target path exists or is inaccessible. BeginTransactionAsync(IsolationLevel, CancellationToken) Begins a new database transaction with the specified isolation level. Task<IDbContextTransaction> BeginTransactionAsync(IsolationLevel isolationLevel = IsolationLevel.ReadCommitted, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters isolationLevel IsolationLevel Defaults to ReadCommitted â€” safest for most operations. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<IDbContextTransaction> An IDbContextTransaction that must be committed or rolled back. Remarks Prefer ExecuteInTransactionAsync<T>(Func<Task<T>>, IsolationLevel, CancellationToken) for most use cases. Manual transaction usage requires proper disposal. EnsureDatabaseCreatedAsync(CancellationToken) Ensures the database file exists and all pending migrations are applied. Safe to call on application startup. Task EnsureDatabaseCreatedAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cancellationToken CancellationToken Returns Task ExecuteInTransactionAsync<T>(Func<Task<T>>, IsolationLevel, CancellationToken) Executes the provided async action inside a new transaction. Automatically commits on success or rolls back on exception. Task<T> ExecuteInTransactionAsync<T>(Func<Task<T>> action, IsolationLevel isolationLevel = IsolationLevel.ReadCommitted, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters action Func<Task<T>> The async lambda or method to execute transactionally. isolationLevel IsolationLevel Transaction isolation level (default: ReadCommitted). cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<T> The result returned by the action. Type Parameters T Return type of the operation (use Unit/Task for void operations). Remarks Recommended pattern for all write operations that should be atomic. Example: await db.ExecuteInTransactionAsync(async () => { await db.Articles.AddAsync(...); await db.SaveChangesAsync(); }); ExecuteRawQueryAsync<T>(string, CancellationToken, params object[]) Executes a raw SQL SELECT query and maps results to a list of entities of type T. Task<List<T>> ExecuteRawQueryAsync<T>(string sql, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default, params object[] parameters) where T : class Parameters sql string Parameterized SQL query (use {0}, {1} placeholders or named parameters). cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. parameters object[] Values to bind to the query parameters. Returns Task<List<T>> List of materialized entities. Type Parameters T Entity type with properties matching column names. Remarks Use for complex queries or performance-critical reads that cannot be expressed via LINQ. Does not track entities by default. ExecuteSqlCommandAsync(string, CancellationToken, params object[]) Executes a non-query SQL command (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, PRAGMA, etc.). Task<int> ExecuteSqlCommandAsync(string sql, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default, params object[] parameters) Parameters sql string Parameterized SQL command. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. parameters object[] Values to bind. Returns Task<int> Number of rows affected. Remarks Ideal for bulk operations, schema changes, or SQLite-specific commands. GetStatisticsAsync(CancellationToken) Retrieves lightweight database statistics (size, counts, last backup). Task<DatabaseStatsDto> GetStatisticsAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cancellationToken CancellationToken Returns Task<DatabaseStatsDto> A DatabaseStatsDto object with current metrics. Remarks Should be fast enough for periodic UI refresh or health monitoring. Counts are approximate when called concurrently with writes. ResetDatabaseAsync(CancellationToken) Deletes all data from all tables (truncate-like behavior) while preserving schema. Intended for development, testing, or user-initiated "clear all data" actions. Task ResetDatabaseAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cancellationToken CancellationToken Returns Task Remarks Should be wrapped in a transaction and confirmed by user. Does not drop/recreate the database file. VacuumAsync(CancellationToken) Executes SQLite VACUUM command to reclaim unused space and defragment the database file. Task VacuumAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cancellationToken CancellationToken Returns Task Remarks Useful after bulk deletes (e.g., article cleanup, archiving). May take significant time on large databases â€” run in background.

api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.R.summary: Interface IArticleRepository Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.Repositories Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Repository interface for managing Article domain entities. Provides comprehensive data access operations including CRUD, specialized queries, bulk status updates, duplicate detection, pagination, search, and maintenance tasks. public interface IArticleRepository : IRepository<Article> Inherited Members IRepository<Article>.FirstOrDefaultAsync(Expression<Func<Article, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Article>.AnyAsync(Expression<Func<Article, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Article>.CountAsync(CancellationToken) IRepository<Article>.DeleteByIdAsync(int, CancellationToken) IRepository<Article>.InsertOrUpdateAsync(Article, CancellationToken) IRepository<Article>.InsertAllAsync(IEnumerable<Article>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Article>.UpdateAllAsync(IEnumerable<Article>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Article>.DeleteAllAsync(CancellationToken) Remarks This repository serves as the primary persistence abstraction for articles in the RSS reader application. It encapsulates all database interactions related to articles, ensuring separation from business logic and enabling testability (e.g., via in-memory or mock implementations). Core responsibilities and behavioral expectations: All write operations should be atomic and transactional where appropriate. Read operations must use indexed columns (FeedId, Status, Guid, ContentHash) for efficiency. Existence and count checks must avoid loading full entities (use scalar queries). Bulk operations are optimized for sync/import/cleanup scenarios. Methods that affect unread counters should trigger recalculation in the implementation. api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.R.summary: Interface IArticleTagRepository Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.Repositories Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Repository interface for managing the many-to-many relationship between Article and Tag entities. Handles tag associations, bulk operations, removal, and usage statistics for articles. public interface IArticleTagRepository : IRepository<ArticleTag> Inherited Members IRepository<ArticleTag>.GetAllAsync(CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.GetByIdAsync(int, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.GetWhereAsync(Expression<Func<ArticleTag, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.FirstOrDefaultAsync(Expression<Func<ArticleTag, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.AnyAsync(Expression<Func<ArticleTag, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.CountAsync(CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.CountWhereAsync(Expression<Func<ArticleTag, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.InsertAsync(ArticleTag, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.UpdateAsync(ArticleTag, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.DeleteAsync(ArticleTag, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.DeleteByIdAsync(int, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.InsertOrUpdateAsync(ArticleTag, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.InsertAllAsync(IEnumerable<ArticleTag>, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.UpdateAllAsync(IEnumerable<ArticleTag>, CancellationToken) IRepository<ArticleTag>.DeleteAllAsync(CancellationToken) Remarks This repository manages the join table ArticleTag, which stores metadata about when and how a tag was applied to an article (e.g., manually by user, automatically by rule, confidence score from ML, etc.). Core responsibilities: Association and disassociation of tags to/from articles (single and bulk) Existence checks and targeted retrieval by article or tag Bulk cleanup (remove all tags from article or tag from all articles) Retrieval of tags with full details or article IDs by tag name Statistics and audit-like queries (recently applied, by rule) Important behavioral expectations: All write operations should be atomic and preferably transactional. Duplicate associations are prevented (unique constraint on ArticleId + TagId). Metadata fields (AppliedBy, RuleId, Confidence) are optional but tracked for auditability and future ML/rule improvements. Removal operations do not cascade to delete tags themselves â€” only the join record. Queries involving tag names may involve joins to the Tag table. Default: "user". ruleId int? ID of the rule that applied the tag (null if manual). confidence double? Confidence score (0.0â€“1.0) if ML-applied; null otherwise. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<bool> true if the association was created; false if already existed. AssociateTagsWithArticleAsync(int, IEnumerable<int>, string, int?, CancellationToken) Associates multiple tags with an article in a single operation. Rule ID if applied by automation (optional). cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<int> Number of new associations created. ExistsAsync(int, int, CancellationToken) Checks if a specific article is already associated with a specific tag. Task<bool> ExistsAsync(int articleId, int tagId, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters articleId int Article ID. tagId int Tag ID. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<bool> true if the association exists; otherwise false. GetArticleIdsByTagNameAsync(string, CancellationToken) Retrieves IDs of all articles associated with a given tag name. Task<List<int>> GetArticleIdsByTagNameAsync(string tagName, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters tagName string Normalized tag name (case-insensitive). cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<List<int>> List of article IDs that have this tag. GetByArticleAndTagAsync(int, int, CancellationToken) Retrieves the exact ArticleTag join record for a given article-tag pair. Task<ArticleTag?> GetByArticleAndTagAsync(int articleId, int tagId, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters articleId int Article ID. tagId int Tag ID. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<ArticleTag> The join entity if exists; otherwise null. GetByArticleIdAsync(int, CancellationToken) Retrieves all tag associations for a given article. Task<List<ArticleTag>> GetByArticleIdAsync(int articleId, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters articleId int The ID of the article to query. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<List<ArticleTag>> List of ArticleTag join entities. GetByTagIdAsync(int, CancellationToken) Retrieves all tag associations for a given tag. Task<List<ArticleTag>> GetByTagIdAsync(int tagId, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters tagId int The ID of the tag to query. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<List<ArticleTag>> List of ArticleTag entities linked to the tag. GetRecentlyAppliedTagsAsync(int, CancellationToken) Retrieves the most recently applied tag associations. Returns Task<List<ArticleTag>> List of ArticleTag ordered by application time descending. GetTagStatisticsForArticleAsync(int, CancellationToken) Computes basic statistics about tag usage on a specific article. Task<Dictionary<string, int>> GetTagStatisticsForArticleAsync(int articleId, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters articleId int Article ID. cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<Dictionary<string, int>> Dictionary of tag name â†’ count. GetTagsAppliedByRuleAsync(int, CancellationToken) Retrieves all tag associations created by a specific rule. Returns Task<List<Tag>> List of detailed Tag objects. RemoveAllTagsFromArticleAsync(int, CancellationToken) Removes all tag associations from a specific article. Returns Task<int> Number of tag associations removed. RemoveTagFromAllArticlesAsync(int, CancellationToken) Removes a tag from every article it is associated with. api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.R.summary: Interface ICategoryRepository Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.Repositories Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Repository interface for managing Category entities, which group RSS feeds into logical folders or collections with support for custom ordering, colors, and hierarchy. public interface ICategoryRepository : IRepository<Category> Inherited Members IRepository<Category>.GetAllAsync(CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.GetByIdAsync(int, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.GetWhereAsync(Expression<Func<Category, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.FirstOrDefaultAsync(Expression<Func<Category, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.AnyAsync(Expression<Func<Category, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.CountAsync(CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.CountWhereAsync(Expression<Func<Category, bool>>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.InsertAsync(Category, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.UpdateAsync(Category, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.DeleteAsync(Category, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.DeleteByIdAsync(int, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.InsertOrUpdateAsync(Category, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.InsertAllAsync(IEnumerable<Category>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.UpdateAllAsync(IEnumerable<Category>, CancellationToken) IRepository<Category>.DeleteAllAsync(CancellationToken) Remarks Categories serve as the primary organizational structure for feeds in the RSS reader. They enable users to group related feeds (e.g., "News", "Technology", "Work", "Personal") and provide visual customization (colors, icons) and sorting. Key responsibilities and behavioral expectations: CRUD operations for categories with validation (unique names, non-empty names) Ordering and reordering support via SortOrder field (user-draggable lists) Unread article count aggregation per category (for badges in feed list/category view) Automatic sort order assignment on creation Change tracking management (detach, clear tracker) for bulk or performance scenarios Business rules: Category names must be unique (case-insensitive in most implementations) Deleting a category does **not** delete feeds â€” feeds become uncategorized (CategoryId = null) SortOrder is 0-based or 1-based (implementation-dependent); gaps are allowed Unread counts include only articles where ArticleStatus = Unread and Feed.CategoryId matches Reorder operations should be atomic (transactional) to prevent inconsistent ordering Performance considerations: GetUnreadCountsByCategoryAsync uses optimized JOIN + GROUP BY (no full entity loading) ReorderAsync should use batch UPDATE or CASE WHEN for efficiency Avoid loading full Category objects when only ID/count is needed Usage scenarios: Sidebar/category tree rendering with unread badges Drag-and-drop reordering in settings New category creation during feed subscription Bulk feed import â†’ auto-create categories if needed Methods ClearChangeTracker() Clears the entire Entity Framework change tracker. void ClearChangeTracker() Remarks Extreme caution advised: only use in bulk import/sync scenarios. api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.R.title: Interface IDatabaseCleanupRepository | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.R.summary: Interface IDatabaseCleanupRepository Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.Repositories Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Repository interface dedicated to low-level database maintenance, cleanup, integrity verification, and performance optimization tasks for the RSS reader SQLite database. public interface IDatabaseCleanupRepository Remarks This repository handles operations that are not tied to specific business entities (like articles or feeds) but are essential for long-term database health, storage management, and performance. Typical use cases: Scheduled nightly/weekly cleanup of old articles Post-import vacuum and reindexing after bulk sync Integrity checks before/after major migrations or backups Monitoring database size and statistics for alerts (e.g., storage nearly full) Dry-run analysis before destructive cleanup operations Important behavioral guidelines for implementations: All methods are asynchronous and fully support CancellationToken. Operations that modify data should be executed with progress reporting. Long-running tasks (VACUUM, REINDEX) may lock the database â€” implementations should use WAL mode. Results DTOs provide detailed feedback for logging/UI. Returns Task<CleanupAnalysis> Analysis result with projected deletion count, and estimated space savings. Returns Task<IntegrityCheckResult> Result object with overall status and any corruption/errors found. Returns Task<ArticleDeletionResult> A result object with deletion statistics. Exceptions ArgumentException When cutoffDate is in the future. Newest)?> GetAffectedArticlesDateRangeAsync(DateTime cutoffDate, bool keepFavorites, bool keepUnread, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cutoffDate DateTime Cutoff date for analysis. keepFavorites bool Exclude favorites? keepUnread bool Exclude unread? cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. Returns Task<(DateTime? Oldest, DateTime? Newest)?> Tuple with oldest and newest publication dates of affected articles (or null if none). Task<long> GetDatabaseSizeAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cancellationToken CancellationToken Cancellation token. api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.R.title: Interface IRepository<T> | NeonSuit RSS Reader API
api/NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.R.summary: Interface IRepository<T> Namespace NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Interfaces.Repositories Assembly NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll Generic repository interface defining standard CRUD, bulk, and query operations for entities in the NeonSuit RSS Reader application. public interface IRepository<T> where T : class, new() Type Parameters T The entity type. Must be a reference type with a parameterless constructor. Remarks All asynchronous methods accept a CancellationToken to support cooperative cancellation and timeout scenarios, especially important in background sync and UI-responsive operations on low-resource hardware. Read operations default to no-tracking for memory efficiency. Write operations are transactional and support concurrency handling. Methods AnyAsync(Expression<Func<T, bool>>, CancellationToken) Checks if any entity matches the specified predicate. Task<bool> AnyAsync(Expression<Func<T, bool>> predicate, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters predicate Expression<Func<T, bool>> Filter expression. cancellationToken CancellationToken Token to cancel the operation. Returns Task<bool> True if at least one matching entity exists. Exceptions OperationCanceledException Thrown if the operation is canceled. Exception Thrown if a database error occurs. CountAsync(CancellationToken) Returns the total number of entities in the table. Task<int> CountAsync(CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters cancellationToken CancellationToken Token to cancel the operation. Returns Task<int> The total count. Exceptions OperationCanceledException Thrown if the operation is canceled. Exception Thrown if a database error occurs. CountWhereAsync(Expression<Func<T, bool>>, CancellationToken) Returns the number of entities matching the specified predicate. Task<int> CountWhereAsync(Expression<Func<T, bool>> predicate, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) Parameters predicate Expression<Func<T, bool>> Filter expression. cancellationToken CancellationToken Token to cancel the operation.
